61887853
Honestly I like this shit. And I made money on it last year buying in hard at 5 cents and holding until 12 cents.

The tech is good - it’s magic to watch hard wallet confirmations happen instantly. The chart still looks painful though, but I’m actively considering starting to acquire again. It’s a spiffy first party wallet to be honest.

Any word on level 2 shit?

61887873
>>61887799
Yonatan here, this is misleading.

Kaspa supports archival nodes and pruned nodes. Bitcoin, Ethereum and most modern Blockchain also prune.
So this is not unique to Kaspa.

The most important distinction you need to realise is that pruning old block data does NOT mean skipping consensus verification. Nodes still validate consensus, enforce rules and track UTXO state. They just don't keep every ancient block at once.

61887902
>>61887873
As we've established, Mr Sompolinsky, it's not that the old blocks weren't kept; they were lost. And a great deal of work has been done to recover what has been lost, but not all of it has been recovered.

Open thread • Replies: 29 • Updated: 2026-02-23 03:15 UTC

OP

Early replies (first 3)

61879648

61879767
>>61879648
getting dumped on by OP

61879836
>>61879767
Due to my current occupation, I am prohibited from holding stocks, options, or similar investments.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61879895
This you?

61879921
>>61879767
idk I mean bed bath was once a huge American retail darling...the historic overstock chart is super schizo/presently quite low...these warrants are trading like a shitcoin which is funny...I also don't dislike lemonis. He's a media player and if you actually listened to some of his shit there does seem to be an interesting intersection between blockchain capabilities and homeownership etc...not financial advice of course just a variety of things I was peeking at when researching

61879944
>>61879263
no

61879999
>>61879836
What is your current occupation anon? Nothing revealing but in general etc...the exercise price of the warrants is $15...trading currently at less than a dollar it seems like a confusing deal...at this point if one likes the company wouldn't shares be the move? I did some modeling around warrant prices if the shares price goes to xyz and that is very interesting...also speaking of interesting what's the deal with the alleged cusip similarity to the old bbbyq shares?

61880091
>>61879999
Financial system. I am not asking you to hold those warrants until they are exercised. I am asking you to hold them and sell the warrants when we can realize a substantial profit. Nice quads.

61881477
>>61880091
Interesting. Wouldn't trading the warrants implicitly come with a short term capital gains tax insofar as its impossible to hold them over a year at this point? Would have to be some pretty fair gains to offset that 40% hit...anyways doesn't the warrants increasing in price also imply that the shares have gone up in price as well? I ran some informal modeling estimates using black scholes with iv, roughly .65 years to expiry and this is what I came up with: 15.5 bbby share price = 4.50ish warrant price...25 share price/12ish warrant price...60 share price/45ish warrant price...100 share price/85ish warrant price...200 share price 185ish warrant price...I make no claim as to the veracity of these numbers, just for fun. Anyways what do you see happening to the bbby stock price for these warrants to be worthwhile? Am I thinking on the right track in general?

61881670
>>61879263

61881753
>>61879999
>>61881477
note the digis

61881916
>>61879263
Buy these if you want, but remember, these warrants are not related to the canceled BBBYQ/DK-Butterfly, reguardless of what the BBBYQ schizos say.

item.title: Passed a Google Senior SWE interview with 0 tech experience — 8 replies — 26.8/hr
item.content:encoded:
Passed a Google Senior SWE interview with 0 tech experience

Open thread • Replies: 8 • Updated: 2026-02-23 03:59 UTC

OP

> Be me, 28-year-old no tech experience , only know basic python from school.
> Have a master's and undergrad in economics, because why not?
> My entire "career" has been freelance strategy consulting for local normies, basically telling them how to restructure their failing businesses from a financial standpoint to survive. It has absolutely zero to do with tech.
> Decide to look into big tech companies in California because I'm bored.
> Find out that Google, Meta, Microsoft, and even smaller places like Uber and Palantir have the most brain-dead, standardized interview processes imaginable.
> The interviewers are completely detached from the actual teams. The whole system is completely gameable. You choose whatever language.
> You can literally just lie on your resume. Make up a fake company or use a real one, tailor the bullshit to exactly what the recruiters want to see.
> There are literally services that will set up fake companies for you to pass the background check. It's that easy.
> The interviews are a joke. It's not about what you know; it's about how well you studied the test.
> Grind leetcode like a monkey. Use Hello Interview. Memorize system design buzzwords.
> Pro tip: Use ChatGPT to generate fake behavioral stories based on whatever BS you put on your resume. Make up highly specific, realistic scenarios where you "saved the day." The interviewers eat it up.
> I literally made up something that is quite literally impossible, and the interviewer still failed to ask follow-ups in the behavioral.
> Just lie on your resume. If you aren't completely retarded, the interviews are gameable.
> If coding isn't your thing try product management, it's even easier and equally as gameable.
> It’s amazing how these interview processes are completely detached from the actual job. Nothing simulates real work anymore. It’s exactly like studying to pass a standardized test. The system is broken, exploit it.

Early replies (first 3)

61889007

clarity starts the next bull run, check em

61888709
Poo poo pee pee caca doo doo wee wee, check em

61888754
Okay hear me out

The potential for 81K is possible though ironically. When you account for staking locking up 95% or even more of the circulating supply(350 Mil, the rest are spoken for on nodes already). I suspect by 2026 BTC will only have around 35-40% dominance as well, projects with specific applications will begin to take hold. Oracles, various layer 1's that enable Smart contracts, DEFI, decentralized cloud computing, decentralized cloud storage, and probably other things that haven't even been conceptualized yet.

We are supposed to see at least 8 Trillion MCAP by 2025 of all crypto according to the experts. Klaus Schwab mentions this in his book.

I think we will see 4-5 Trillion at the peak of the next bullrun easy. That will probably be early to mid 2022. Next peak bull run will probably mid to late 2026 which could easily run 16-20 Trillion MCAP of all crypto. In the scheme of things that is only around 18-25% of the global GDP. Its honestly not that much.

Now lets say LINK network protocol captures 4 Trillion by 2026 peak bull run. At even 80% staking saturation (70 Million circulating supply) the price is close to 60,000 per LINK, around 57,000. At 15% circulating supply, its 52.5 Million LINK with a 4 Trillion MCAP is 76,000 per LINK.

These numbers sound ridiculous at first or to the uniniated but again when you understand what LINK is/does its honestly not. We are buying a share of the fat protocol that will monetize Web 3.0. I mean think if HTTPS would have been monetized. The Internet itself is worth around 19 Trillion and when you add in data accumulated from the "Internet of Things", it adds a 5-10x multiplier roughly.

The Internet is more or less 25 years old for the masses as a whole. If there were 350 Million shares circulating, they would be worth just under 54,000 each at its current estimated value.

The pic related is fun and entertaining but ironically achievable in the time frame suggested

Discuss

61888841
>>61888754

61888854
$1000 EOY

item.title: Is it even possible to make it by opening a traditional business anymore? — 27 replies — 8.2/hr
item.content:encoded:
Is it even possible to make it by opening a traditional business anymore?

Open thread • Replies: 27 • Updated: 2026-02-23 00:59 UTC

OP

Read subject

Is it even possible? Not only do you have to jump through a million regulations and fees just to get started, you're also competing against trillion dollar mega corps who can and will undercut you because they employ ten thousand indians and illegals who work for pennies. Even traditional blue collar jobs like plumbers and HVAC are all slowly coagulating into one single corporate entity (in my area), and basically every single mom and pop store was killed during COVID.

It seems like the only way you can actually achieve anything is to basically trick angle investors into giving your bullshit tech start-up a ton of money or getting really lucky and have an app you make be bought out by a megacorp so they can rape your customers to death.

Pic unrelated

Early replies (first 3)

61881446
>>61881439

Step 2: have her start an ASMR channel on YouTube
Step 3: have her start a merchandise line on shopify
There.

Do you have anything more realistic that I can accomplish?

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61882459
>>61881439
Even trillion dollar companies can't do everything. The amount of bureaucracy involved to manage such a large entity is limiting in its own ways.
You have to find a niche that isn't currently being served in your market and then create a business for that.
For example: nobody is making catgirl gfs right now, it's a completely untapped market.

61882478
Corporations can now grow indefinetly due to advancement's in economic planning. It used to be theyd crash and burn after they got to a certain size.

61882649

61883247
>>61881439
It's possible, but made very difficult by design. Can't have too many people escaping the wage cage.

Everything is over regulated, because it means only mega corps have the resources to deal with the BS.

61883254
>>61881439

but you're right about consolidation and private equity ownership. there's no way around this, other than killing PE jews or the people who sell out to PE.

61883298
>>61881446

>have gf
>she films herself having sex with guys in college while we were long distance

61883454
>>61883298
disgusting freak. why marry at this point?

61883460
>>61883454
It's bait anon. No one has a GF here on 4chin

61884102
>>61881624
>>61882584
kill yourselves.

61884346
>>61881439
Welcome to the patent system!
* invent something new under the sun
* spend a few thousand dollars with a patent attorney to protect your invention in an airtight manner
* sue the shit out of anyone who infringes
* make outsized profits on everything you sell

I vaguely remember being told by one of my patent law professors during law school that over 80% of profits in the U.S. are tied to intellectual property, i.e., patents and copyrights. Commodity goods just aren't profitable when you have to compete by selling as close to zero margin as you can get, and make it up on volume.

A company called Rare Breed is doing that right now in the field of "forced reset trigger systems" for firearms. Their projections are that they will make mid-eight figures of profit annually if they are the sole source. Note "profit" not "revenue". Manufacturing costs on each of their units is probably around $50, and they're selling them for $500 each.

The difficulty: lots of infringers, including one batshit insane asshole from Arizona, and one kid who designed a free one that anyone can 3D print at home. (And in all fairness, the kid put it out on free 3D printing websites before several of Rare Breed's patents issued, but after they were filed, so he arguably wasn't even infringing at the time.) They've got something like seventeen lawsuits going right now, IIRC, and some of the defendants are trying to get their cases consolidated into a single trial because of the expense.

61884359
It's like getting into the in-game market in an MMO that's been around for 20 years, it's completely futile

61884385
>>61881624
>>61882584
picrelated

61884627
Of course it is. Where do you think all these giant houses come from? There's tons of well-off business owners all throughout your city, state, country.

61886156
>>61884627
Most of whom got started a couple of generations ago. Then they set up legislative roadblocks to make it impossible for new competitors to spring up.

My state requires a 1000 hour training certificate before someone can cut hair. As a result, a large percentage of those who do it are guys who were stuck in prison and learned their trade in the prison barbershop, because it was free for them.

61886164
>>61884627
Oh, I forgot about the used car lots. Used to be that anyone could set up as a used car dealer. Then the big stealerships started getting outcompeted, with one big driver (heh) being because the independents would stay open on Sundays while the stealerships were closed. So the stealerships lobbied the legislature to prohibit used car lots from being open on Sundays.

Lots more similar stories in various businesses. Funeral parlors are heavily regulated (the excuse being "they can dispose of bodies in their crematoriums, so we have to regulate and license that profession"), and so on and so on.

FFS in NYC Mamdani just asked for "volunteer snow shovelers" and demanded that they register with """""""""""The City""""""' by showing two forms of ID plus their Social Security card.

61886443
>>61886156
Reminds me of this
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ouP2qhTF3x4
In Oklahoma you need a funeral director's license to sell coffins
>In order to become a licensed funeral director in Oklahoma, an individual must have a high school diploma or GED, complete a minimum two-year accredited mortuary science program, and pass the National Board Exam and the Oklahoma State Board of Mortuary Arts Exam. After completing the educational requirements, the individual must also complete a one-year apprenticeship in an Oklahoma funeral home.
All that just to sell a box.

61886977
>>61884346
Lol. No. It does not work like that. Only companies with in house lawyers benefit from patents, and they are mostly defensive.

61887004
>>61881439
Well, now is the time to start a business what with the new tariffs.
But it is not easy, and depending on your personality, may or may not be worth it. Judging from OPs attitude, its not worth it for him.
The path easiest for good money with least effort is to become a corporate drone. You gotta learn to speak the lingo and be agreeable and subservient. This is why they want a college degree.
Watch the movie "office space" for a comedic and yet canny take on corporate life. Its easy boring shit, but just like in the movie you will find yourself dreaming about working on a road crew or something.

61887017
yeah but you have to understand the end game. its not to run a business, it's to build a profitable business to sell to private equity. build a business doing plumbing hvac whatever, get reliable cashflow, get customers, sell it. rinse and repeat. one of my good friends does this with hvac, finds an under served area, spend 2-3 years building it and sell off to a mega corp. easily in the 8 figure club in his 40s

61887038
>>61881439
yeah like John the Baptist
we're born alone and we die alone
take what you need then forget it

61887480
Your options are so limited it’s unreal. Even doctors who were private practice are becoming wagies for big hospital systems. Shit is fucked.

61888491
>>61887004
>the new tariffs
You mean the ones they just shot down? Even if they somehow did add 50% tarrifs or whatever the fuck Trump is planning it wouldn't matter because you can't compete with slave labor wages in China/India/Whatever. Nobody gives a fuck if you produce it down the street from them if it means they can get it for ten cents cheaper, even if the quality is garbage. Price is the ONLY thing that matters.

all other macro bottoms took several months of crabbing before the markets went up again, we havent done that yet
probably better to wait it out and only deploy capital when its clear the trend has shifted
